articles.headline: Judge a Tax Plan by Its Loopholes
articles.snippet: Paul Ryan’s plan on taxes has won points for conviction, but the document leaves some significant questions unanswered.
articles.abstract: Paul Ryan’s plan on taxes has won points for conviction, but the document leaves some significant questions unanswered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Having touched the third rail of American politics last year — proposed cuts to entitlements like Medicare — and lived to fight another day, Representative Paul Ryan was back this week with a revised Republican budget proposal and another storm of criticism. His budget “slashes the safety net to pay for tax cuts mostly for wealthy Americans“(a column in The Washington Post); is one in which “the rich pay less in taxes than the unfairly low rates they pay now” (an editorial in The New York Times); and “would shower the wealthiest few Americans with an average tax cut of at least $150,000” (the White House).

articles.headline: Companies Pick Up Used Packaging, and Recycling’s Cost
articles.snippet: While government requirements for recycling remain limited, pressure from environmentally minded consumers and the cost advantages of reusing materials are bringing change.
articles.abstract: While government requirements for recycling remain limited, pressure from environmentally minded consumers and the cost advantages of reusing materials are bringing change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brushing your teeth with a yogurt container? Wiping your mouth with a coffee cup?

articles.headline: Spain Is Not Out of the Woods Yet
articles.snippet: Fiscal austerity and a real estate bust are threatening to set off a vicious economic circle in Spain similar to the one that has pummeled Greece.
articles.abstract: Fiscal austerity and a real estate bust are threatening to set off a vicious economic circle in Spain similar to the one that has pummeled Greece.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Officials from Washington to Frankfurt have recently declared that the worst is over for the euro zone.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Time to Tune Up the Portfolio
articles.snippet: As markets move up and down, it’s a good idea to rebalance your investments periodically to ensure that the proportions you desire still hold.
articles.abstract: As markets move up and down, it’s a good idea to rebalance your investments periodically to ensure that the proportions you desire still hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: So much of our financial lives requires regular maintenance — whether it’s updating who’s going to inherit what, checking that you’re not paying too much for car insurance or making sure your investments, particularly your retirements savings, are still working for you.

articles.headline: Gay Marriage Effort Attracts a Novel Group of Donors
articles.snippet: A fund-raising network seeking to legalize same-sex marriage from coast to coast includes a different set of contributors from those who have supported other gay-related issues.
articles.abstract: A fund-raising network seeking to legalize same-sex marriage from coast to coast includes a different set of contributors from those who have supported other gay-related issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a warm Friday afternoon three years ago, Rob Reiner, the director, arrived for lunch at the Beverly Hills estate of David Geffen, the entertainment mogul. Mr. Reiner and his political adviser, Chad H. Griffin, had spent six months drafting an ambitious legal campaign aimed at persuading the United States Supreme Court to establish a constitutional right of same-sex marriage.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: A Personal Note as Obama Speaks on Death of Boy
articles.snippet: Calling the killing of a 17-year-old in Florida “a tragedy,” President Obama said, “If I had a son, he’d look like Trayvon.”
articles.abstract: Calling the killing of a 17-year-old in Florida “a tragedy,” President Obama said, “If I had a son, he’d look like Trayvon.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama did not mention race even as he addressed it on Friday, instead letting his person and his words say it all: “If I had a son, he’d look like Trayvon.”
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: On the Right, Santorum Has Women’s Vote
articles.snippet: Conservative women have formed a core of Rick Santorum’s support since the primaries began, drawn by his message of family values and his personal biography.
articles.abstract: Conservative women have formed a core of Rick Santorum’s support since the primaries began, drawn by his message of family values and his personal biography.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANDEVILLE, La. — Rick Santorum was running late, and about 250 people were growing restless at a rally sponsored by the Tea Party. So the Harris sisters, a country singing duo, took the stage.

articles.headline: Islamist Victors in Egypt Seeking Shift by Hamas
articles.snippet: The Muslim Brotherhood is overhauling its relations with the two main Palestinian factions, Hamas and Fatah, in an effort to put new pressure on Israel for an independent Palestinian state.
articles.abstract: The Muslim Brotherhood is overhauling its relations with the two main Palestinian factions, Hamas and Fatah, in an effort to put new pressure on Israel for an independent Palestinian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As it prepares to take power in Egypt, the Muslim Brotherhood is overhauling its relations with the two main Palestinian factions in an effort to put new pressure on Israel for an independent Palestinian state.

articles.headline: Insuring Hollywood Against Falls (but Not Flops)
articles.snippet: In the film world, Fireman’s Fund has become the go-to company for insuring against production injuries and accidents.
articles.abstract: In the film world, Fireman’s Fund has become the go-to company for insuring against production injuries and accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE’S one for “The Hunger Games” crowd: What if, in that blood-tingling climactic scene near the Cornucopia, Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence) had skewered poor Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson) with a wayward silver arrow?

articles.headline: Just the Facts. Yes, All of Them.
articles.snippet: Gilad Elbaz has a big mission for Factual, his start-up company: Identify every existing fact to build the world’s chief reference point.
articles.abstract: Gilad Elbaz has a big mission for Factual, his start-up company: Identify every existing fact to build the world’s chief reference point.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

articles.headline: A Bailout by Another Name
articles.snippet: Requiring Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to write down principal on mortgages held by troubled borrowers would add to taxpayer losses — and result in a different form of a bailout for banks.
articles.abstract: Requiring Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to write down principal on mortgages held by troubled borrowers would add to taxpayer losses — and result in a different form of a bailout for banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: ED DeMARCO is a marked man.

articles.headline: Mangled Horses, Maimed Jockeys
articles.snippet: The new economics of horse racing are making an always-dangerous game even more so, as lax oversight puts animal and rider at risk.
articles.abstract: The new economics of horse racing are making an always-dangerous game even more so, as lax oversight puts animal and rider at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUIDOSO, N.M. — At 2:11 p.m., as two ambulances waited with motors running, 10 horses burst from the starting gate at Ruidoso Downs Race Track 6,900 feet up in New Mexico’s Sacramento Mountains.
articles.byline: By WALT BOGDANICH, JOE DRAPE, DARA L. MILES and GRIFFIN PALMER

articles.headline: In Europe, Where Art Is Life, Ax Falls on Public Financing
articles.snippet: Europe’s economic problems, and the austerity programs meant to address them, are forcing arts institutions there to curtail programs, tours and grants.
articles.abstract: Europe’s economic problems, and the austerity programs meant to address them, are forcing arts institutions there to curtail programs, tours and grants.
articles.lead_paragraph: European governments are cutting their support for culture, and American arts lovers are starting to feel the results.

articles.headline: U.S. Plans No Charges Over Deadly Strike in Pakistan
articles.snippet: American officials, finding a chain of mistakes by both sides, have decided no service members will face disciplinary charges in a November airstrike that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers.
articles.abstract: American officials, finding a chain of mistakes by both sides, have decided no service members will face disciplinary charges in a November airstrike that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States military has decided that no service members will face disciplinary charges for their involvement in a NATO airstrike in November that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers, an accident that plunged relations between the two countries to new depths and has greatly complicated the allied mission in Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Groups Blanket Supreme Court on Health Care
articles.snippet: The nine justices will need steely nerves to block out all the noise surrounding its review this week of the Obama administration’s sweeping health care law.
articles.abstract: The nine justices will need steely nerves to block out all the noise surrounding its review this week of the Obama administration’s sweeping health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas likens all the outside political pressure that the Supreme Court is facing over its review of the Obama administration’s sweeping health care law to the distraction faced by a free-throw shooter confronted with fans waving wildly behind the basket. Neither, in his view, has much impact in the end.

articles.headline: Kennedy Helped Shape Romney’s Career, and Still Haunts It
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s complicated relationship with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, from campaign foe to health care partner, helped shape both his political career and his image.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s complicated relationship with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, from campaign foe to health care partner, helped shape both his political career and his image.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Gov. Mitt Romney signed legislation in April 2006 requiring most Massachusetts residents to have health coverage, Senator Edward M. Kennedy stood by his side, beaming like a proud father. They were onstage at historic Faneuil Hall in Boston, a setting that had a special resonance for the two.

articles.headline: For Cheney, 71, New Heart Ends 20-Month Wait
articles.snippet: Former Vice President Dick Cheney is recovering at a Virginia hospital after awaiting a heart transplant for more than 20 months.
articles.abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney is recovering at a Virginia hospital after awaiting a heart transplant for more than 20 months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Dick Cheney had a heart transplant on Saturday after 20 months on a waiting list, and was recovering in a Virginia hospital, a statement from his office said.

articles.headline: In Slain Teenager’s Case, a Long Route to National Attention
articles.snippet: It took several weeks, after word spread on Facebook and Twitter of the shooting of Trayvon Martin, for the news to become widely reported by the national media.
articles.abstract: It took several weeks, after word spread on Facebook and Twitter of the shooting of Trayvon Martin, for the news to become widely reported by the national media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old, was fatally shot on Feb. 26 in Sanford, Fla. The next day his death was a top story on the Fox-affiliated television station in Orlando, the closest big city to Sanford. Within a week it was being covered by newspapers around the state.

articles.headline: In Health Care Case, Lawyers Train for 3-Day Marathon
articles.snippet: Practice sessions for the lawyers debating President Obama’s health care law in Supreme Court arguments this week have stretched the supply of colleagues willing to play the justices.
articles.abstract: Practice sessions for the lawyers debating President Obama’s health care law in Supreme Court arguments this week have stretched the supply of colleagues willing to play the justices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The three days of Supreme Court arguments that start Monday on the constitutionality of President Obama’s health care law will be a legal marathon, and the lawyers involved have been training.

articles.headline: With Summit of Arab Leaders, Iraq Seeks to Shift Image
articles.snippet: For Iraqi diplomats and officials, a three-day meeting of the Arab League is a banner moment for a country emerging from decades of war, occupation and diplomatic isolation.
articles.abstract: For Iraqi diplomats and officials, a three-day meeting of the Arab League is a banner moment for a country emerging from decades of war, occupation and diplomatic isolation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As Arab leaders converge on Baghdad for a landmark summit meeting this week, they will be treated to carefully chosen glimpses of a new Iraq: gleaming hotel lobbies, renovated palaces and young palm trees lining an airport highway once called the Road of Death.

articles.headline: Hashtag Activism, and Its Limits
articles.snippet: Online movements are probably not as effective as real world engagement, but occasionally they are powerful beyond the computer.
articles.abstract: Online movements are probably not as effective as real world engagement, but occasionally they are powerful beyond the computer.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you “like” something, does that mean you care about it?

articles.headline: Anger at Goldman Still Simmers
articles.snippet: Testifying recently in a lawsuit that is unrelated to Copper River’s closing, its chief maintained that actions taken in the fall of 2008 by Goldman Sachs had done irreparable damage to his fund.
articles.abstract: Testifying recently in a lawsuit that is unrelated to Copper River’s closing, its chief maintained that actions taken in the fall of 2008 by Goldman Sachs had done irreparable damage to his fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just before the financial crisis began in September 2008, a prominent hedge fund appeared well positioned to take advantage of any turmoil in the markets. That fund, Copper River Partners, had made sizable bets months earlier against companies whose stocks it expected to suffer.

articles.headline: Not Worth the Paper It’s Built On
articles.snippet: After losing everything in the collapse of the Irish economy, Frank Buckley built his home from bricks made out of shredded, decommissioned euro notes.
articles.abstract: After losing everything in the collapse of the Irish economy, Frank Buckley built his home from bricks made out of shredded, decommissioned euro notes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — As an emblem of the modern Irish condition, Frank Buckley is almost too apt. Dead broke, he lives in a house made of money.

articles.headline: Wielding Fire, Islamists Target Nigeria Schools
articles.snippet: For a town in northern Nigeria already living in fear of a violent Islamist group, the arson of school buildings is the latest outrage.
articles.abstract: For a town in northern Nigeria already living in fear of a violent Islamist group, the arson of school buildings is the latest outrage.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — The teenager in the immaculate white robe stood in the ruins of what had been his school. There were no classrooms, no desks or chairs, no intact blackboards — there was, in fact, no longer any reason for him to be there.

articles.headline: Once Neighboring Congressmen, Iowans Compete for Same Seat
articles.snippet: Redistricting in Iowa has pitted two longtime members of the house, Tom Latham, a Republican, and Leonard L. Boswell, a Democrat, against each other.
articles.abstract: Redistricting in Iowa has pitted two longtime members of the house, Tom Latham, a Republican, and Leonard L. Boswell, a Democrat, against each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: URBANDALE, Iowa — Representative Tom Latham cut into a frosted cinnamon roll roughly the size of his face and listened intently as a group of small-business owners lit into him about sprinkler rules and federal financial regulations. It was the second of a dozen meetings on a recent Wednesday in one of the counties in his native Iowa that Mr. Latham, a Republican, has not represented before in Congress.

articles.headline: Microsoft Raids Tackle Internet Crime
articles.snippet: The computer software giant won a court order to enter two Web hosting facilities last week in a war against so-called botnets that scour the Internet for personal data to steal and exploit.
articles.abstract: The computer software giant won a court order to enter two Web hosting facilities last week in a war against so-called botnets that scour the Internet for personal data to steal and exploit.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft employees, accompanied by United States marshals, raided two nondescript office buildings in Pennsylvania and Illinois on Friday, aiming to disrupt one of the most pernicious forms of online crime today — botnets, or groups of computers that help harvest bank account passwords and other personal information from millions of other computers.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: U.S. Agency Seeks Tougher Consumer Privacy Rules
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission asked for legislation that would give consumers access to the information collected on them by so-called data brokers.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission asked for legislation that would give consumers access to the information collected on them by so-called data brokers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government’s chief consumer protection agency said on Monday that it intended to take direct aim at the vast industry that has grown up around the buying and selling of information about American consumers.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega and Edward Wyatt
